channel.title: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Hundreds Of Chechens Join ISIS, Including Group's No. 2 Leader
item.description: Rebels from Chechnya have joined ranks with other jihadists in ISIS. David Greene talks to Gordan Hahn, author of Russia's Islamic Threat and an analyst for the Geostrategic Forecasting Corporation.
item.content:encoded:
Rebels from Chechnya have joined ranks with other jihadists in ISIS. David Greene talks to Gordan Hahn, author of Russia's Islamic Threat and an analyst for the Geostrategic Forecasting Corporation.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Romanian Hub Used By U.S. Military Is In A Strategic Location
item.description: There are 30,000 U.S. troops in Afghanistan and 20,000 will head home shortly. Millions of them transited in and out through a base in Kyrgyzstan, until the government there didn't renew the lease.
item.content:encoded:
There are 30,000 U.S. troops in Afghanistan and 20,000 will head home shortly. Millions of them transited in and out through a base in Kyrgyzstan, until the government there didn't renew the lease.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Sean Carberry

item.title: Hong Kong Activists To Counter China's Electoral Interference
item.description: Don Gonyea talks to Anson Chan, former chief secretary of Hong Kong, about China exercising control over Hong Kong's next leadership election. Pro-democracy supporters are outraged.
item.content:encoded:
Don Gonyea talks to Anson Chan, former chief secretary of Hong Kong, about China exercising control over Hong Kong's next leadership election. Pro-democracy supporters are outraged.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Ukraine Crisis Requires A New Rulebook, Author Says
item.description: David Greene talks to Edward Lucas, senior editor at The Economist and author of The New Cold War, about what moves NATO should be considering in response to Russian military moves in Ukraine.
item.content:encoded:
David Greene talks to Edward Lucas, senior editor at The Economist and author of The New Cold War, about what moves NATO should be considering in response to Russian military moves in Ukraine.

» E-Mail This

item.title: How Do We Stop Ebola? WHO Declares War On The Virus
item.description: Over the next six months, about 20,000 people will get Ebola. Half will likely die. To stop the virus, the World Health Organization says it needs thousands of health care workers and $600 million.
item.content:encoded:
Over the next six months, about 20,000 people will get Ebola. Half will likely die. To stop the virus, the World Health Organization says it needs thousands of health care workers and $600 million.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: Report: Violence Against Children Runs Rampant In Nigeria's Northeast
item.description: A group that tracks violence against children is reporting "grave violations" in Nigeria's fragile northeast. Violence there is getting worse, the group says, despite a state of emergency in some states and the "Bring Back Our Girls" campaign that raised awareness of the children kidnapped by the militant group Boko Haram.
item.content:encoded:
A group that tracks violence against children is reporting "grave violations" in Nigeria's fragile northeast. Violence there is getting worse, the group says, despite a state of emergency in some states and the "Bring Back Our Girls" campaign that raised awareness of the children kidnapped by the militant group Boko Haram.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Michele Kelemen

item.title: Response In Ukraine Could Prove A Crucible For NATO's Future
item.description: To learn more about the NATO summit in Wales this week, Melissa Block speaks with Admiral James Stavridis, dean of the Fletcher School at Tufts University and former supreme allied commander at NATO.
item.content:encoded:
To learn more about the NATO summit in Wales this week, Melissa Block speaks with Admiral James Stavridis, dean of the Fletcher School at Tufts University and former supreme allied commander at NATO.

» E-Mail This

item.title: World Leaders Descend On Wales To Help Decide NATO's Way Forward
item.description: President Obama is attending the NATO summit in Wales, which some people are calling the most important in decades. On the agenda are Russia's intentions in Ukraine and the threats posed by the Islamic State.
item.content:encoded:
President Obama is attending the NATO summit in Wales, which some people are calling the most important in decades. On the agenda are Russia's intentions in Ukraine and the threats posed by the Islamic State.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Ari Shapiro

item.title: Remembering Shacki: Liberia's Accidental Ebola Victim
item.description: Shacki Kamara went out to buy his aunt some tea. Then she heard from the neighborhood kids: "They shot Shacki." He died the next day. Eva Nah is still asking why.
item.content:encoded:
Shacki Kamara went out to buy his aunt some tea. Then she heard from the neighborhood kids: "They shot Shacki." He died the next day. Eva Nah is still asking why.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Ofeibea Quist-Arcton

item.title: Chill Out, Pie-Makers. There's No Butter Shortage Looming
item.description: Butter prices are at their highest levels in years, and supplies are low. But it's not because Americans suddenly discovered that fat isn't evil. It's because other countries love our butter, too.
item.content:encoded:
Butter prices are at their highest levels in years, and supplies are low. But it's not because Americans suddenly discovered that fat isn't evil. It's because other countries love our butter, too.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Allison Aubrey and April Fulton

item.title: A Few Ebola Cases Likely In U.S., Air Traffic Analysis Predicts
item.description: What are the chances somebody with Ebola will fly to the U.S. by late September? One team of scientists says it could be as high as 18 percent. And the risk is even higher for the U.K.
item.content:encoded:
What are the chances somebody with Ebola will fly to the U.S. by late September? One team of scientists says it could be as high as 18 percent. And the risk is even higher for the U.K.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Richard Knox

item.title: Liberia's Information Minister Admits Mistakes, Defends Actions
item.description: In efforts to defeat Ebola, the government could have done better, says Lewis Brown. But he stands by the tough calls that have been made — including the controversial quarantine in West Point.
item.content:encoded:
In efforts to defeat Ebola, the government could have done better, says Lewis Brown. But he stands by the tough calls that have been made — including the controversial quarantine in West Point.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Ofeibea Quist-Arcton

item.title: Russians React To Western Food Ban With Pride, Resignation
item.description: As NATO discusses the crisis in Ukraine this week, Russia's ban on Western imports of fresh food marches on. For now, Moscow's grocery shelves are still stocked, and citizens are stoic.
item.content:encoded:
As NATO discusses the crisis in Ukraine this week, Russia's ban on Western imports of fresh food marches on. For now, Moscow's grocery shelves are still stocked, and citizens are stoic.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian

item.title: Legal Troubles Dog Famed Spanish Architect Santiago Calatrava
item.description: A Spanish court named Calatrava, designer of New York's Ground Zero transport hub, a suspect in alleged contract fraud. Prosecutors say he got $3.6 million for a convention center that wasn't built.
item.content:encoded:
A Spanish court named Calatrava, designer of New York's Ground Zero transport hub, a suspect in alleged contract fraud. Prosecutors say he got $3.6 million for a convention center that wasn't built.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: Baltic States Battle Russian Media Blitz
item.description: The Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are trying to counter what they say is a flood of intense propaganda from Russian media that broadcast just across the border.
item.content:encoded:
The Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are trying to counter what they say is a flood of intense propaganda from Russian media that broadcast just across the border.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Corey Flintoff
